message_1: A manufacturer produces light bulbs and claims that on average they last for 8000 hours with a standard deviation of 200 hours. A random sample of 50 bulbs was taken and their average lifespan was found to be 7950 hours. Calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true average lifespan of the bulbs.
message_2:
To calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true average lifespan of the bulbs, we will use the following formula:

Confidence Interval = Sample Mean ± (Critical Value * Standard Error)

where:
Sample Mean = 7950 hours (given)
Sample Size (n) = 50 (given)
Population Standard Deviation (σ) = 200 hours (given)
Critical Value (z) = 1.96 (for a 95% confidence interval)

First, we need to calculate the Standard Error (SE):

Standard Error (SE) = σ / √n
SE = 200 / √50
SE ≈ 28.28 hours

Now, we can calculate the margin of error:

Margin of Error = Critical Value * Standard Error
Margin of Error = 1.96 * 28.28
Margin of Error ≈ 55.43 hours

Finally, we can calculate the confidence interval:

Confidence Interval = Sample Mean ± Margin of Error
Confidence Interval = 7950 ± 55.43
Confidence Interval = (7894.57, 8005.43)

So, we can be 95% confident that the true average lifespan of the bulbs is between 7894.57 hours and 8005.43 hours.
